data.title: Add SeqTsEchoHeader, and align new end-to-end stats header
data.description:
This combines the lingering patch from bugzilla issue 2111: https://www.nsnam.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=2111 on a SeqTsHeader variant that has an additional timestamp field, and my suggested changes to Natale's recent E2E stats commit.

I removed the #pragma once directives since we are not using those on the project; if we were to move to those, we should handle as a separate issue, but the last time that I tried to use them, they caused issues with Clang finding headers twice, and I am not sure they are worth the trouble with our current build system that has headers in multiple places.

I renamed the 'E2EStats' naming for consistency with the other headers, and because this is also not really providing any stats but is just exporting a header to enable client code to compute stats.

I still have a concern that this is not robust to the case where the bulk send application creates the header and then the call to Socket::Send() returns without copying all of the bytes.  It seems to be possible for headers to be truncated or skipped when the socket buffer is full, causing mistakes on the receiver side.  Probably some test code is needed to explore this, and possibly some buffering of incomplete writes on the sender side.

notes_data.body:
I'm belatedly realizing I should pay attention to the E2E stats work.  (I'm only 5 years late)

IIUC the additional data are being sent *within the packet buffer, as data*, not as a tag?  That's surprising, since the extra bytes alter the traffic flow itself.  Is it too late to reconsider?

data.title: Integration of the 3GPP TR 38.901 pathloss and channel condition models (GSoC 2019)
data.description:
I added new classes implementing the pathloss and the LOS/NLOS condition models specified in 3GPP TR 38.901.

In particular, this MR contains:
- a new abstract class ChannelConditionModel, which provides the base for the implementation of specific channel condition models. The main method is GetChannelCondition (mm a, mm b), which determines the channel condition based on the tx and rx mobility models and returns it as a pointer to an object of type ChannelCondition
- the implementation of the subclasses ThreeGppRMaChannelConditionModel, ThreeGppUMaChannelConditionModel, ThreeGppUMiStreetCanyonChannelConditionModel, ThreeGppIndoorMixedOfficeChannelConditionModel, ThreeGppIndoorOpenOfficeChannelConditionModel, which inherits from ChannelConditionModel and statistically determines the LOS/NLOS state based on the specification in 3GPP TR 38.901
- the implementation of the subclass BuildingsChannelConditionModel, which inherits from ChannelConditionModel and determines the LOS/NLOS state based on the buildings deployed in the scenario. It has been adapted from the mmwave module.
- new classes which extends the PropagationLossModel interface and implements the pathloss models defined in 3GPP TR 38.901 (ThreeGppRmaPropagationLossModel, ThreeGppUmaPropagationLossModel, ThreeGppUmiStreeCanyonPropagationLossModel, ThreeGppIndoorOfficePropagationLossModel). The main method is DoCalcRxPower (txPow, mm a, mm b), which applies the pathloss model taking into account the LOS/NLOS channel state and then returns the received power. To retrieve the channel state, they interface with the class ChannelConditionModel through the method GetChannelCondition (mm a, mm b)
- documentation and test cases for all the new classes

I would like to have your opinion on the following issue:
the pathloss model should be used for BS-UT links and to compute the pathloss value we need to know hBS (the height of the base station) and hUT (the height of the user terminal). The TR specifies the validity range for these values. However, we may need to use them also for UT-UT or BS-BS links, e.g., when computing the interference, and in these cases we are not able to set the value of hBS (in the UT-UT case) or hUT (in the BS-BS case). In my implementation, the missing value is set as close as possible to the actual height of the node but inside the corresponding validity range. Do you think this is reasonable?

notes_data.body: changed the description
I don't see any usage of aggregation in this patch.
Do you have any contacts in industry/3GPP who can answer this question about how others (in their own link-sims based on 38.901) have handled this issue?
I am not seeing the need to define an ns3::Object to basically wrap a two-state enum.
bool 'IsWithinLineOfSight' might be a more natural name

If this is not defined as 3e8 in the spec, I suggest to use:
  static const double C = 299792458.0; // speed of light in vacuum

because it is elsewhere in propagation-loss-model.cc set to that value (and a few years ago, there was a discussion and cleanup of slightly differing values for C found around the codebase).

is it worth it to consider std::cerr warnings instead of NS_LOG_WARN? Most people do not run simulations with this log component enabled, and may be running in optimized mode.  I might lean towards cerr just to be more explicit about it, if the validity is really a concern.
suggest 'a warning log message is printed if the user has enabled logging on the model'.
Also need to enforce an upper bound of 23 m to use this formula.

All this part could be refactored into a protected method of parent class if m_uniformVar could also be put in parent class. This would avoid having to rewrite all the code on min and max setting of this attribute in all the child classes. This attribute would be ignored for `BuildingsChannelConditionModel`.
This part could also be refactored in parent class
s/`()`/`(void) const` (same comment for other classes)
Update parameter names in doxy (same comment for other classes)

Update parameter names in doxy (same comment for all other occurrences of `GetBsHeight` and `GetUtHeight`).

Also provide units.
Add paramters' names in doxy
s/`opèrating`/`operating`. Same comment for following classes.
Provide units for all attributes (and also arguments). Same comment for all classes.
Provide units

Shouldn't the `0.5 and 7 GHz` range be enforced here? Same comment (with appropriate range) for next classes.

Is it because you want to leave 0 and check if initialized in the DoCalcRxPower method?
Wouldn't it be better to set a practical frequency (e.g. 3.5 GHz) here?

Have you considered using an intermediate abstract parent class (i.e. between the base PropagationLossModel and these) so as to avoid having to rewrite methods such as these? A lot of attributes also seem to be common and could be set as protected in this intermediate abstract parent class.

No check on BS and UT heights for LOS? The table states that the applicability range should be applied to both LOS and NLOS, even though it is true that these variables are not used in LOS pathloss computations.
Add space after `,` namely inside pow
PL2 is composed of PL1. It would be better to have a private method `static double ComputePathloss1 (double d)` so as to avoid having to rewrite the same code twice (error-prone).
As stated above, a method for this would have been nice (Calculate2dDistance?)

This assumption is very reasonable and smart. However, you'll need to enforce it to the provided positions (min(hA, hB) should be capped to 13m in what follows). Also check BS height (which should be 25m).
Same comment as above for hUT max and hBS enforcement

The standard is not very clear about this point but should the distance ranges be checked for NLOS in this optional formula? If so, consider moving the check (here and elsewhere) to the calling class.
Shadowing is applied twice, since GetLossLos also adds it!
Shadowing is applied twice, since GetLossLos also adds it!
Haven't reviewed the test-suites.

Unfortunately no, I would like to know how they do, too. I have found some guidelines in the WINNER II specifications (https://www.cept.org/files/8339/winner2%20-%20final%20report.pdf, sec. 5.1.4) and after a discussion with Nat and the 5G-LENA team we decided to use the fourth approach called "Exact interference by multi-cell modelling".
In TR 38.901 c is defined as 3.0e8 m/s
Yes, I wanted to be sure that users do not forget to set the frequency

I had the same idea but I decided not to implement it because, as you figured out, some derived classes may not use it. Notice that this is the same approach used in the class PropagationLossModel. Anyway, if you think that it is better to define it in the parent class I can change it.
Yes, I thought about it. In my opinion multiple inheritance would worsen the code clarity, but it is just my own opinion. What do you think in this regard?
I do not know, in my understanding they applies only to the standard one but maybe I'm wrong

Hi Tommaso,

I think that it would be better to refactor as much as possible (just like what has been apparently done in LTE MAC schedulers and that's also the logic in most wifi module classes); it'll improve the clarity of the code. Maybe having somebody else's opinion on this point would be nice.
OK clear now.
Already replied above.
OK maybe we could keep it this way then.
Discussed in ns-developers

I agree but I think it should be defined in the Vector3D class, I can open a MR for this

This already exists, for both [Vector2D](https://www.nsnam.org/docs/doxygen/classns3_1_1_vector2_d.html#ae17f0bb09a310c1e62e1cf2f0f667486) and [Vector3D](https://www.nsnam.org/docs/doxygen/classns3_1_1_vector3_d.html#a0d454b609d1dd69a7d1104056b88f1f3)

Since you're starting with MobilityModels, there is also [MobilityModel::GetDistanceFrom()](https://www.nsnam.org/docs/doxygen/classns3_1_1_mobility_model.html#a3eadc9abaf084587d5aa9e5d92e613fe)

The method Vector3D::CalculateDistance does not work in this case because I need to compute the 2D distance (sqrt (x^2 + y^2)). Alternatively I could do like this Vector2D::CalculateDistance (Vector2D (a->GetPosition ().x, a->GetPosition ().y), Vector2D (b->GetPosition ().x, b->GetPosition ().y)), but in my opinion it is not very clear.

Agree that is awkward.  On the other hand, the use cases for 2D distance from 3D vector are so limited, I'd wouldn't want to add that to the Vector3D api.  In addition, since ns-3 doesn't define the coordinate system, such a call in Vector3D isn't always meaningful.  For example, if I assume ECEF coordinates, not planar Cartesian, then the horizontal plane isn't X-Y...

It seems odd that the 3GPP models explicitly use 2D distance for what is in reality a 3D pathless...
Good point! I think the best option for the moment is to compute the 2D distance "by hand", like I do now. If I find a better solution I will update it

One of the requirement for this model was to make it possible to use it even when the heights of the two nodes are not 3GPP compliant. This is because users may want to simulate scenarios which are very different from the 3GPP ones and also because we would like to have the possibility to model UT-UT and BS-BS channels. For this reason, I cannot enforce BS and UT heights. I tried to do this in a reasonable way but I think it can be still improved. For instance, an easy thing that would help is to have the possibility to know the type of the two devices (UT or BS). I would like to have more opinions on this.
This was done to make it easy to extend the model, i.e., other models which may have additional information other than the LOS/NLOS state can aggregate it to this object.

However, I think it is better to use the regular model, so I improved the assignment of hBs and hUt and I updated the classes implementing pathloss models accordingly
- I improved the interface between the base class ThreeGppPropagationLossModel and the derived classes
- as suggested by Rediet, I updated the classes implementing the channel condition model to include some checks to test if BS and UT heights are within the validity range
I added a warning message if hUT > 23

Hi Tom,

> My reading of the code is that the shadowing loss is updated (changed) every UpdatePeriod (e.g. 100ms) even for stationary nodes. This doesn't align with my intuition; if the geometry of a scenario is unchanging, why would shadowing loss change? I looked in 38.901 and couldn't find justification for this. Please correct if I am wrong, but if there isn't a requirement for this, can you change the code to avoid loss changes for stationary nodes? 

There is not a specific requirement. Given that, at this stage, we decided not to include the spatial consistency update procedure, we agreed to generate an independent channel realization at each UpdatePeriod. When including this procedure, the new shadowing value will be correlated with the previous one, and the autocorrelation function depends on the distance travelled (see 38.901, Sec. 7.4.4).

> There is a special value of UpdatePeriod of Seconds (0) that leads to no update being performed, but this is not documented. 

Ok, I will add it 

> However, I wonder if it would be better to have each model provide a default channel condition model that could be optionally changed. It seems that channel condition objects are paired with corresponding typed 3GPP loss models. It seems to me that some time point after loss model construction (e.g. initialization time just before running) would be the time to do this, but offhand, I do not know whether Object::Initialize() is called on propagation loss models. I suggest to implement a dummy Initialize() and see if it is called, and if so, then add the default channel condition model there. If not, then I think we should take steps in ns-3 to see that Initialize() would be called for propagation loss models. 

In general I agree with you, but when using both the ThreeGppPropagationLossModel and the ThreeGppSpectrumPropgationLossModel, they need to be associated with the same instance of ChannelConditionModel. Hence, hiding its creation in the method ThreeGppPropagationLossModel::Intialize ()  would not simplify the procedure, because then you need to retrieve it and then set it in the ThreeGppSpectrumPropgationLossModel.

> None of the tests or examples makes use of mobility other than ConstantPositionMobilityModel. Is this because of issue 80 (i.e. is it because mobility doesn't really work)? I suggest that at least some test involving mobility be added. 

Yes, I wanted to use a ConstantVelocityMobilityModel to test the class BuildingsChannelConditionModel but it is not possible because of issue 80.

> Finally, the tests do not run clean under valgrind:
> 
> ./waf --valgrind --run 'test-runner --suite=buildings-channel-condition-model'
> 
> * buildings-channel-condition-model
> * channel-condition-model
> * three-gpp-propagation-loss-model

Ok, I will check.

Best,
Tommaso

I reviewed this again because we would like to merge this work as soon as possible, but I have some concerns that I would like to have addressed before merge.

I think that issue #80 should be resolved in tandem with this merge; when else is it going to be addressed if not now?  At minimum, I think we need to have a correct model even if it is computationally inefficient, but I also agree with Peter's comment that we should try to find opportunities to update only when necessary.

My reading of the code is that the shadowing loss is updated (changed) every UpdatePeriod (e.g. 100ms) even for stationary nodes.  This doesn't align with my intuition; if the geometry of a scenario is unchanging, why would shadowing loss change?  I looked in 38.901 and couldn't find justification for this.  Please correct if I am wrong, but if there isn't a requirement for this, can you change the code to avoid loss changes for stationary nodes?

There is a special value of UpdatePeriod of Seconds (0) that leads to no update being performed, but this is not documented.

I have some concerns about the need for users to explicitly set channel condition model; if not done, the model will assert.  For instance, I think that use in an LTE example will require something like this:

```
   Ptr <LteHelper> lteHelper = CreateObject<LteHelper> ();
   Ptr<ChannelConditionModel> condModel = CreateObject<ThreeGppIndoorMixedOfficeChannelConditionModel> ();
   lteHelper->SetAttribute ("PathlossModel", StringValue ("ns3::ThreeGppIndoorOfficePropagationLossModel"));
   lteHelper->SetPathlossModelAttribute ("ChannelConditionModel", PointerValue (condModel));
```
At minimum, even though this code is not LTE specific, I think it is worth mentioning in the Sphinx documentation that this extra step is required for usage; i.e. it is not sufficient to change the propagation loss model from, for instance, "BuildingsPropagationLossModel" to one of the 3GPP ones without instantiating and adding this extra object.

However, I wonder if it would be better to have each model provide a default channel condition model that could be optionally changed.  It seems that channel condition objects are paired with corresponding typed 3GPP loss models.  It seems to me that some time point after loss model construction (e.g. initialization time just before running) would be the time to do this, but offhand, I do not know whether Object::Initialize() is called on propagation loss models.  I suggest to implement a dummy Initialize() and see if it is called, and if so, then add the default channel condition model there.  If not, then I think we should take steps in ns-3 to see that Initialize() would be called for propagation loss models.

None of the tests or examples makes use of mobility other than ConstantPositionMobilityModel.  Is this because of issue 80 (i.e. is it because mobility doesn't really work)?  I suggest that at least some test involving mobility be added.

Finally, the tests do not run clean under valgrind:

./waf --valgrind --run 'test-runner --suite=buildings-channel-condition-model'

- buildings-channel-condition-model
- channel-condition-model
- three-gpp-propagation-loss-model

I tried all the tests, but only buildings-channel-condition-model is not running properly.  
This test checks if the channel condition is correctly determined by calling the method "GetChannelCondition" on an instance of the class BuildingsChannelConditionModel, without using the simulator. Valgrind shows some memory leaks which seem to be due to the Node class. It seems that if I do not call Simulator::Destroy (), some memory blocks remain reachable after the execution of the test. Instead, if I call Simulator::Destroy (), all the memory is freed. Is this a possible solution?
Yes, Simulator::Destroy() is usually required to clear up the valgrind warnings.

>  When including this procedure, the new shadowing value will be correlated with the previous one, and the autocorrelation function depends on the distance travelled (see 38.901, Sec. 7.4.4).

I'm not convinced by this.  Sec. 7.4.4 concerns the spatial autocorrelation, not the temporal.  Traditionally, large scale shadowing is a process on the timescale of seconds, not 100ms.  Can you please find some more justification for 100ms default, or why this update should not default to the value 0 (disabled)?

Can you also point me to where in the code that the new shadowing value is correlated with the previous one?  I see, for instance, in ThreeGppRmaPropagationLossModel::ComputeShadowing() that a new random variable is drawn without regard for the previous value.

It seems to me that the 38.901 model asks for a mean large-scale path loss, then a zero-mean shadowing component depending on LOS/NLOS, and so there are two random variable draws (one for determining LOS/NLOS, and then one for the shadowing), and then if there is a movement to a new position, the model should be updated, but conceptually, the LOS/NLOS outcome and the shadowing component should be correlated to the previous values depending on distance travelled.  38.901 Sec. 7.4.4 addresses the normalized autocorrelation for the shadowing component, but I couldn't find reference to how successive values of LOS/NLOS are correlated.  I also could not find reference to support updating these values periodically (100ms).   It doesn't seem that your code checks for change in position either; perhaps it relies instead on this 100ms update.  It seems conceptually wrong to me that a stationary node could be toggling between LOS and NLOS state every 100ms.

> In general I agree with you, but when using both the ThreeGppPropagationLossModel and the ThreeGppSpectrumPropgationLossModel, they need to be associated with the same instance of ChannelConditionModel. Hence, hiding its creation in the method ThreeGppPropagationLossModel::Intialize () would not simplify the procedure, because then you need to retrieve it and then set it in the ThreeGppSpectrumPropgationLossModel.

Should channel condition belong to the channel, then, rather than the propagation model(s)?

Hi Tom,
my two cents for the above-6 GHz part: as far as I know, there are no (or few) measurements papers that study how the parameters of the mmWave channel evolve in time (i.e., how they are correlated over time for a stationary user). This is why I believe the 3GPP only considers correlation in the spatial sense in 7.7.4. There may be more studies in the sub-6 GHz region but I am not an expert on that.

I think that Tommaso's approach to keep a parameter for the update is the best we can do for now. 
As of the default value, I believe 100 ms was chosen in the original NYU code base as default for channel updates to reflect that the mmWave channel may evolve with faster dynamics than a sub-6 GHz one https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2811619
However, I am fine also with setting it to 0 and document this feature - with the risk that users that do not read the docs only use static channels.

Michele

> I'm not convinced by this. Sec. 7.4.4 concerns the spatial autocorrelation, not the temporal. Traditionally, large scale shadowing is a process on the timescale of seconds, not 100ms. Can you please find some more justification for 100ms default, or why this update should not default to the value 0 (disabled)? 

There is not a specific reason. As Michele said, this was the default value in the NYU implementation. I'm fine if you want to change it.

> Can you also point me to where in the code that the new shadowing value is correlated with the previous one? I see, for instance, in ThreeGppRmaPropagationLossModel::ComputeShadowing() that a new random variable is drawn without regard for the previous value. 

As I said, at the moment an independent channel realization is generated at each UpdatePeriod. I would like to add the shadowing correlation when including the  spatial consistency procedure (Sec. 7.6.3.2). However, if you think this is a mandatory feature I can add it to this MR (but I need some time because I am a bit busy in these days).

>  It seems to me that the 38.901 model asks for a mean large-scale path loss, then a zero-mean shadowing component depending on LOS/NLOS, and so there are two random variable draws (one for determining LOS/NLOS, and then one for the shadowing), and then if there is a movement to a new position, the model should be updated, but conceptually, the LOS/NLOS outcome and the shadowing component should be correlated to the previous values depending on distance travelled. 38.901 Sec. 7.4.4 addresses the normalized autocorrelation for the shadowing component, but I couldn't find reference to how successive values of LOS/NLOS are correlated. I also could not find reference to support updating these values periodically (100ms). It doesn't seem that your code checks for change in position either; perhaps it relies instead on this 100ms update. It seems conceptually wrong to me that a stationary node could be toggling between LOS and NLOS state every 100ms.

Sec. 7.6.3.3 describes how to correlate the LOS probability, and this will be part of the spatial consistency procedure as well. My code does not check changes in the position because an independent channel realization is generated at each update period. As you said, maybe is better to disable by default the possibility to periodically update the LOS state.

>  Should channel condition belong to the channel, then, rather than the propagation model(s)?

Yes, I did so because I did not want to introduce changes in the existing classes. I think that adding the channel condition model to the channel is the best option.

>  As I said, at the moment an independent channel realization is generated at each UpdatePeriod. I would like to add the shadowing correlation when including the spatial consistency procedure (Sec. 7.6.3.2). However, if you think this is a mandatory feature I can add it to this MR (but I need some time because I am a bit busy in these days).

I realize that I am coming in late with substantial comments, but I am not proposing that you address these all right now.  However, I would like the documentation to be very clear about what is modelled and what remains for future work.  I think that at least one new paragraph should be added to the Sphinx that covers the spatial (lack of) and temporal updating to the model.  Whether we change the default or not is somewhat secondary to documenting what the default behavior is, and why one may want to change it.

data.title: Integration of the 3GPP TR 38.901 fast fading model (GSoC 2019)
data.description:
This MR contains new classes implementing the fast fading model described in 3GPP TR 38.901, Sec. 7.5 and new models for antenna arrays.

In particular:

* the class ThreeGppChannel implements the procedure to generate the channel matrix

* the class ThreeGppSpectrumPropagationLossModel extends the SpectrumPropagationLossModel interface. It computes the received PSD by applying the beamforming and accounting for the small scale fading

* the example three-gpp-channel-example shows how to configure the 3GPP channel model classes to compute the SNR between two nodes

* the class AntennaArrayBasicModel provides an interface for the modeling of antenna arrays supporting beamforming operations

* the class AntennaArrayModel models an isotropic rectangular antenna array

* documentation and test cases are provided

**Note**: to use this branch rebase it on top of three-gpp-channel (https://gitlab.com/tommasozugno/ns-3-dev/tree/three-gpp-channel)

Hi Sian,

Yes, you are right. For the moment we decided to generate an independent realization each time. One of the next steps will be the addition of the spatially consistent update procedure (including the correlation of the shadow fading).

Thanks,
Tommaso

Hi Tommaso:

I find in Section 7.4.4 of TR38.901, the shadow fading is colored, i.e., its correlation coefficient matrix (with different entry corresponds to different steps of distance x) is not an identity matrix. But three-gpp-propagation-loss-model.cc seems assuming that the the shadow fading is white and shadow fading in different distance are independent. So, three-gpp-propagation-loss-model.cc uses a scalar Gaussian random variable as the shadow fading at each specific distance. Is my understanding correct?

Sian

>  three-gpp-channel.cc: line 824 is incorrect according to TR 38.901 equation (7.5-8), "if(cIndex == 0)" should be changed into "if(cIndex == 1)"

Today I will check, this function was taken from the mmwave module code.

> antenna-array-model.cc:this seems nothing new compared with its parent AntennaArrayBasicModel. Is this because TR 38.901 does not specify beamforming in section 7.4-7.5? 

AntennaArrayBasicModel is a base class for all the antenna array classes. The derived classes differs with respect to the specific radiation pattern. At the moment I added a single antenna implementation, but I plan to add another model implementing the 3GPP radiation pattern soon.

Best,
Tommaso

Hi Tommaso:
There are few comments w.r.t. your code.

three-gpp-channel.cc: line 824 is incorrect according to TR 38.901 equation (7.5-8),  "if(cIndex == 0)" should be changed into "if(cIndex == 1)"

antenna-array-model.cc:this seems nothing new compared with its parent AntennaArrayBasicModel. Is this because TR 38.901 does not specify beamforming in section 7.4-7.5?

Sian

>  three-gpp-channel.cc: line 824 is incorrect according to TR 38.901 equation (7.5-8), "if(cIndex == 0)" should be changed into "if(cIndex == 1)"

At page 32 it is written "In case of LOS condition an additional specular component is added to the first cluster." 
The TR assumes that the index of the first cluster is 1, this is why they use delta(n-1).

This class has a map where the pairs <device, beforming vector> are stored. The method Set is used to insert/update an entry in the map, while the method Change is used to update the antenna weight with one of the bf vectors present in the map. I will clarify this in the doc and the doxy
GetBeamformingVector is used to retrieve one of the bf vectors in the map, while GetCurrentBeamformingVector returns the bf vector in use. I will clarify this as well.

TR 38.901 describes a calibration procedure that can be used to validate the model, but it requires several additional features which are not currently implemented. I discussed about this with my mentors and we decided not to include the validation part in the gsoc project because of the required time. The tests checks if the implemented procedures works as expected, but they do not check the single entries of the channel matrix.
Hi Tom! I did not have time to work on this, I will try to address your comments asap.
What is the updated status of this?  We seemed to be close to merge in October.

Hi Tommaso: 

Is fast fading used in three-gpp-channel-example.cc? Here is what I find: 

In ComputeSnr method, rxPsd is obtained using CalcRxPowerSpectralDensity. When I trace back to ThreeGppSpectrumPropagationLossModel::DoCalcRxPowerSpectralDensity, I find only beamforming gain is applied. 

What I'm thinking is: a fast fading channel H(t, tau) is not static when you transmit each individual packet. So, the resulting received power at receiver's each subcarrier is also time-varying. So, we cannot use traditional Fourier transform to calculate receiver PSD. In Section 6.3 of 'Wireless Communications' written by Andreas F. Molish, the formula for calculating receiver signal PSD over a time-varying channel is provided (pls see the attached file). So, if we need to calculate PSD for a fast fading channel, we need to use the formula here. While traditional Fourier transform based PSD calculation is suitable for slow fading channel, for example, the IEEE TGn channel, which is in the form of H(tau).  

![IMG_0564](/uploads/65877d5edeee189ddaf55135d00c763d/IMG_0564.jpg) 

Sian

Hi Sian,

I am not sure I correctly understood your question. I used the approach described here https://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.04822.pdf (see Sec. 5.2). The only dependence of t and tau in the channel impulse response are due to the Doppler term and the delays, hence the transform operation is trivial. To reduce the complexity, the authors decided to apply the Doppler component cluster by cluster, considering only the central angle.

>  What I'm thinking is: a fast fading channel H(t, tau) is not static when you transmit each individual packet.

We cannot simulate intra-packet channel variations, we have a single PSD value per PHY packet.

Best,
Tommaso

Hi Tommaso:

I'm reading your code three-gpp-spectrum-propagation-loss-model.cc. Two quick questions: what's the definition of longTerm and what formula did you use to convert the time-domain channel matrix into a frequency domain subsbandGain?

Thanks,
Sian

I see. Thank you so much!

Sian

Hi! See equation (2) and (4) [here](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1702.04822.pdf). longTerm is a vector which stores the long term components related to all the clusters, i.e., the product between the beamforming vectors and the channel matrix for a given cluster (H_n).

According to 3GPP TR 38.901 v15.0.0 (2018-06) section 7.6.4.1, the blocking region for self-blocking is provided in LCS. 
However, here, `clusterAOA` and `clusterZOA` are seemingly in GCS and blocking check is performed for self-blocking similar to non-self blocking, that is in GCS.
One would expect the angles to be transposed to LCS before checking self-blockage.

data.title: Smart Event implementation
data.description:
A SmartEvent (the name is subject to discussion) is similar to a Watchdog but it's fundamentally different.

A SmartEvent isn't "pinged", it's rescheduled. You can reschedule it how you want, even with decreased delay. It will "smartly" handle this by canceling and rescheduling its internal event when necessary.

Its application is for events that are frequently extended (like a watchdog) but they could be also decreased.

Moreover, unlike a Watchdog, it can be canceled.

data.title: Fix MacOs build failure
data.description:
This MR fixes the MacOs build failure reported by @stavallo . 
The reported issue was: 
```
Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:

      ThreeGppRmaPropagationLossModelTestCase::DoRun() in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o

  "ns3::MobilityBuildingInfo::MakeConsistent(ns3::Ptr<ns3::MobilityModel>)", referenced from:
      ThreeGppRmaPropagationLossModelTestCase::DoRun() in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o

  "ns3::MobilityBuildingInfo::GetTypeId()", referenced from:
      ns3::Ptr<ns3::MobilityBuildingInfo> ns3::Object::GetObject<ns3::MobilityBuildingInfo>() const in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o
  "ns3::BuildingsChannelConditionModel::GetTypeId()", referenced from:
      ns3::Ptr<ns3::BuildingsChannelConditionModel> ns3::CompleteConstruct<ns3::BuildingsChannelConditionModel>(ns3::BuildingsChannelConditionModel*) in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o
  "ns3::BuildingsChannelConditionModel::BuildingsChannelConditionModel()", referenced from:
      ns3::Ptr<ns3::BuildingsChannelConditionModel> ns3::CreateObject<ns3::BuildingsChannelConditionModel>() in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o
  "ns3::Building::SetBoundaries(ns3::Box)", referenced from:

      ThreeGppUmaPropagationLossModelTestCase::DoRun() in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o

      ThreeGppIndoorOfficePropagationLossModelTestCase::DoRun() in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o
      ThreeGppShadowingTestCase::RunTest(unsigned short, std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >, double, double, double, bool) in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o
  "ns3::Building::Building()", referenced from:
      ns3::Ptr<ns3::Building> ns3::Create<ns3::Building>() in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o
  "typeinfo for ns3::MobilityBuildingInfo", referenced from:
      ns3::Ptr<ns3::MobilityBuildingInfo> ns3::Object::GetObject<ns3::MobilityBuildingInfo>() const in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.3.o
ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture x86_64
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
```

I solved this problem by removing the usage of Buildings objects in three-gpp-propagation-loss-model-test-suite.cc.

data.title: More flexible create module.py
data.description:
This is a continuation of https://codereview.appspot.com/343030043/

Consider a project in contrib which wants this structure pulled from a single repo:

```
contrib/
    wscript
    project/
        .repo            // could be .git or .hg, for example
        main/
            wscript      // builds executable 'project' from main.cc and other.cc
            main.cc
            other.cc
        modules/
            moduleA/     // Contains normal module structure
              wscript
              model/
              ...
            moduleB/     // Contains normal module structure
        data/            // No source code here, so no wscript
```

One can't do this at the moment for two reasons:

* contrib/wscript won't recognize the project directory because the top level does not contain a wscript file
* Each "normal" module directory has to be created by hand, or created in src, then moved to its final location.

This patch provides two enhancements to enable this kind of project:

1. Enable the create-module.py script to create modules in the contrib directory, as well as the src directory.
1. Enable modules in the contrib directory to have arbitrary structure.

To accomplish these goals the patch modifies a couple of heuristics:

* create-module.py accepts arbitrary paths, using the last path element as the name of the module.
* contrib/wscript walks the directory tree, looking for directories containing wscript files. When found, add that directory to the list of contrib modules to process. It is not an error for a tree under contrib not to contain any wscript files; this tree is simply ignored. (The data directory above is an example.)

Since create-module.py is more general, this patch moves it to the utils directory.

commits.title: More flexible create-module.py script
commits.message:
More flexible create-module.py script

Changed the default creation directory from src/ to contrib/
  Moved create-modules.py from src/ to utils/

Added two new optional command line arguments: --project and --use-src-dir
--project specifies a directory name or path under which the new modules
will be created.
--use-src-dir directs the script to create new modules in the src
directory instead of contrib.  This argument cannot be combined
with --project.

Updated contrib/wscript to search for modules at
arbitrary depths instead of just the child directories under
contrib.

Assume the following directory structure:
contrib/
  project1/
    module1/
      wscript
    module2/
      wscript
  project2/
    sub_project1/
      	module3/
        	wscript
      	module4/
        	wscript
    sub_project2/
      	module5/
        	wscript
      	module6/
        	wscript
    data/
  module7/
    wscript

waf configure will discover the following modules under contrib:
project1/module1
project1/module2
project2/sub_project1/module3
project2/sub_project1/module4
project2/sub_project2/module5
project2/sub_project2/module6
module7

commits.title: Integration of the 3GPP TR 38.901 pathloss and channel condition model (GSoC 2019) (1/2)
commits.message:
Integration of the 3GPP TR 38.901 pathloss and channel condition model (GSoC 2019) (1/2)

In particular, this commit contains:

* a new abstract class ChannelConditionModel, which provides the base for the
 implementation of specific channel condition models. The main method is
 GetChannelCondition (mm a, mm b), which determines the channel condition
 based on the tx and rx mobility models and returns it as a pointer to an
 object of type ChannelCondition
* the implementation of the subclasses ThreeGppRMaChannelConditionModel,
 ThreeGppUMaChannelConditionModel, ThreeGppUMiStreetCanyonChannelConditionModel,
 ThreeGppIndoorMixedOfficeChannelConditionModel,
 ThreeGppIndoorOpenOfficeChannelConditionModel, which inherits from
 ChannelConditionModel and statistically determines the LOS/NLOS state based on
 the specification in 3GPP TR 38.901
* the implementation of the subclass BuildingsChannelConditionModel, which
 inherits from ChannelConditionModel and determines the LOS/NLOS state based
 on the buildings deployed in the scenario. It has been adapted from the
 mmwave module.
* new classes which extends the PropagationLossModel interface and implements
 the pathloss models defined in 3GPP TR 38.901
 (ThreeGppRmaPropagationLossModel, ThreeGppUmaPropagationLossModel,
 ThreeGppUmiStreeCanyonPropagationLossModel,
 ThreeGppIndoorOfficePropagationLossModel). The main method is DoCalcRxPower
 (txPow, mm a, mm b), which applies the pathloss model taking into account the
 LOS/NLOS channel state and then returns the received power. To retrieve the
 channel state, they interface with the class ChannelConditionModel through
 the method GetChannelCondition (mm a, mm b)
* documentation and test cases for all the new classes

commits.title: app: E2E stats header
commits.message:
app: E2E stats header

Right now, there is no way of extracting e2e statistics without using flow monitor. This patch enables, with an attribute, the possibility of adding a particular header to the outgoing packets, that will be read from PacketSink. The header contains Sequence, Size, and Timestamp, and therefore at the reception, it is possible to measure throughput and per-packet delay.

  wifi: Switch to busy after RX end when necessary
  wifi: Fix reset of some variables in WifiPhy when a packet is dropped
  wifi: Use uint32_t instead of double for band bandwidth expressed in Hz
  wifi: Do not receive a packet sent with an unsupported channel width
  wifi: Fix InterferenceHelper to use non-HT for all calculations before payload
  Fix (for real) NS_DEPRECATED_3_31

  ...

commits.title: Updated create-module script to support creating modules in contrib
commits.message:
Updated create-module script to support creating modules in contrib

Moved create-modules.py from src/ to utils/

Changed the default creation directory from src/ to contrib/

Added two new optional command line arguments: --project and --use-src-dir
--project specifies a directory name or path under which the new modules
will be created.
--use-src-dir directs the script to create new modules in the src
directory instead of contrib.  This argument cannot be combined
with --project.

Updated contrib/wscript to search for modules at
arbitrary depths instead of just the child directories under
contrib.

Assume the following directory structure:
contrib/
  project1/
    module1/
      wscript
    module2/
      wscript
  project2/
    sub_project1/
      module3/
        wscript
      module4/
        wscript
    sub_project2/
      module5/
        wscript
      module6/
        wscript
        data/
  module7/
    wscript

waf configure will discover the following modules under contrib:
  project1/module1
  project1/module2
  project2/sub_project1/module3
  project2/sub_project1/module4
  project2/sub_project2/module5
  project2/sub_project2/module6
  module7

data.title: Fragment optimization
data.description:
See also #153 and #136.

IPv4, IPv6 and SixLowPan fragments was sued to generate one Event in the Scheduler for each fragmented packet.
This patch allows to reduce the events to *at most* one per node, thanks to the fact that all the events have the very same delay.
This is far more efficient than the previous approach, also thanks to the fact that timeout "events" are removed using their iterators, which makes the removal complexity O(1) instead of O(log n).

notes_data.body:
added 21 commits
  • 90d81cc8...59af9d2b - 20 commits from branch nsnam:master
  • 8526db60 - Merge branch 'master' of https://gitlab.com/nsnam/ns-3-dev.git into FragmentOptimization
[Compare with previous version](/nsnam/ns-3-dev/-/merge_requests/200/diffs?diff_id=77236221&start_sha=90d81cc8c4ac6366a7a08993f5b9b427a738a36e)

added 4 commits
  • 8526db60...8d4297f2 - 3 commits from branch nsnam:master
  • 428a8f40 - Merge branch 'master' of https://gitlab.com/nsnam/ns-3-dev.git into FragmentOptimization
[Compare with previous version](/nsnam/ns-3-dev/-/merge_requests/200/diffs?diff_id=77418299&start_sha=8526db60b70306dce6296ddf50fa1783c864050e)

Tested with MacOS, and a modified version of tcp-large-transfer, where every packet is fragmented into 5 fragments by an intermediate router.

| | Old | New |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| Time | 2021.33 | 2024.31 |
| Max Memory | 45854720 | 41914368 |

The execution time is *about* the same (the difference is below statistical significance).
However, the memory is far less: about a 10% reduction.

This will definitely help when the memory is so large that the system goes on swap.
Even though I think that a simulation shouldn't hit the swap point, it is a direct indication that the Scheduler Event queue is reduced by a great deal.

I'm planning to apply this patch if there are no objections.

[Compare with previous version](/nsnam/ns-3-dev/-/merge_requests/200/diffs?diff_id=79674216&start_sha=01f6f97c301925dd4b1d1f2445da7087f3a532b1)

I made some further tests with Eitan's test script. Here are the results.
*  Build: optimized.
*  Script: see #136, "Test 2".
*  Number of tests ran: 20 for each case.
*  Metering method: `/usr/bin/time -v`
*  Example command: `repeat 20 { /usr/bin/time -v -a -o fragmopt2.log ./build/scratch/tcp-bulk-send --stop=10000000 --maxBytes=10000000000000 }`
*  Test machine: Ubuntu 18.04, with plenty of memory, AMD thread ripper.

I ran the test in 3 cases:
*  Baseline (normal ns-3-dev, 2d190e17)
*  FragmOpt 1 (https://gitlab.com/nsnam/ns-3-dev/-/merge_requests/200/diffs?commit_id=8ef39922a03684160b3cab92645ffdd07678f10b)
*  FragmOpt 2 (https://gitlab.com/nsnam/ns-3-dev/-/merge_requests/200/diffs?commit_id=7389537b4be8b9cd708a0503a447b8f6a005e574)

Note that the "real" difference between the 2 Fragmentation Option cases is the use of emplace_back instead
of push_back for some tuples.

As we can see from the graphs below, FragmOpt2 is, statistically speaking, similar to the normal ns-3.
I'll run other tests in more normal cases, because my earlier test (on a MacOS) was definitely going toward the FragmOpt solution.

![Time](/uploads/833fa7b518207e39b058eca805ae98fd/Time.png)

![Memory](/uploads/ccf3a9f7c3b085df6ca8d64e248a2135/Memory.png)

Ok, more tests. This time I used tcp-large-tranfer, slightly modify (it's attached).

[tcp-large-transfer.cc](/uploads/38a7f87fbeb2f9ef7f68c2788058ae27/tcp-large-transfer.cc)

In this case the fragment optimization shows its benefits.
This makes me think that the main memory footprint of Eitan's bulk-send is not due to fragments.

![Time](/uploads/8c397bd0950d839cd1c244c21df259cf/Time.png)

![Memory](/uploads/088cd4b1871fdc1856088da213014fe6/Memory.png)

Hi Tommaso,
Did you try a simple Remove(event) instead of event.Cancel()?
If so what were your results?

Indeed my case showed almost no dependency on the fragments implementation.

Eitan

New results:
*  Baseline is "plain" ns-3
*  FragmOpt2 is the latest Fragment optimization
*  BaselineRemove is using Remove instead of Cancel

Remove is not (statistically speaking) better than Cancel, at least for the Fragments. Neither the Fragment Optimization is - in this case. Memory-wise is the same.

Given all the tests, I'd apply the Fragment Optimization.

![Memory](/uploads/ce159adde513159a91e8735481fc18b7/Memory.png)
![Time](/uploads/b6e65df97206b70401dc2ca5e1ad8408/Time.png)

data.title: wifi: More MAC changes/fixes
data.description:
This MR has multiple purposes:

*  Fix issues with stalled Block Ack window at the recipient. Basically, a BAR is sent as long as there are non-expired outstanding MPDUs. Afterwards, a BAR is queued but it is only sent when the originator has other frames to transmit to the recipient (to avoid that a BAR might be transmitted indefinitely, e.g., when the recipient is gone)

*  Reduce unnecessary packet copy operations, so that packets forwarded up by the receiving MAC match those received by the sender MAC

*  Handle BARs as normal MPDUs (in preparation for handling MU-BAR Trigger Frames)

notes_data.body: changed milestone to %4
changed the description
changed the description

I didn't check netanim, I only verified that the issue with the mixed-wired-wireless example is fixed by the PHY-related commits that I pulled. Of course, it is appropriate to push the pre-OFDMA PHY changes first and then this MR. I pulled some PHY changes just because I wanted to avoid merge conflicts when picking commits from my branch.

I also was unsure about another MR for MAC changes because I thought it would have caused a lot of conflicts. Instead, it turned out to be quite simple once those PHY changes were pulled.
mentioned in merge request !95
Just replied on !95. I confirm that it's a CopyByteTag issue.

```suggestion:-2+0
   * \param skipIfNoData do not send if there is no data queued
   * \param tid the Traffic ID
   */
  Bar (Ptr<const WifiMacQueueItem> bar, uint8_t tid, bool skipIfNoData = false);
```
The comment just above apparently needs to be updated since were forwarding down the copy. Maybe mentioning that it concerns only the forwarded up packet...
Is it possible that `dist == 0`? Since there should be at least one MPDU in the PSDU, I don't see how it can happen...
The comment above refers to the need of preserving the user priority. Can you please suggest how you would like it to be modified?

Ah OK, didn't understand what UP meant.

Maybe we could just add something like:
```
\\ Anyhow, forward down a copy of the packet (while the packet itself
\\ is forwarded up to higher layers).
```
just below the other comment.
Apart for the point discussed in !95 (pertaining to the trace source at MAC/PHY layer), I have no further comments/suggestions.

data.title: core: (fixes 2815) Config::Connect should throw warnings
data.description:
This patch logs unconditionally when a trace path doesn't exist.

We also provide FailSafe versions of Config::Connect and Config::ConnectWithoutContext. These should be used when you can't be sure that a trace path exists in the current model.

This resolves the warnings from AnimationInterface::ConnectCallbacks()

Credit to "InquisitivePenguin (GCI 2019) <>" for diagnosing this issue, opening the way to a solution.

commits.title: More flexible create-module.py script
commits.message:
More flexible create-module.py script

Changed the default creation directory from src/ to contrib/
  Moved create-modules.py from src/ to utils/

Added two new optional command line arguments: --project and --use-src-dir
--project specifies a directory name or path under which the new modules
will be created.
--use-src-dir directs the script to create new modules in the src
directory instead of contrib.  This argument cannot be combined
with --project.

Updated contrib/wscript to search for modules at
arbitrary depths instead of just the child directories under
contrib.

Assume the following directory structure:
contrib/
  project1/
    module1/
      wscript
    module2/
      wscript
  project2/
    sub_project1/
      	module3/
        	wscript
      	module4/
        	wscript
    sub_project2/
      	module5/
        	wscript
      	module6/
        	wscript
    data/
  module7/
    wscript

waf configure will discover the following modules under contrib:
project1/module1
project1/module2
project2/sub_project1/module3
project2/sub_project1/module4
project2/sub_project2/module5
project2/sub_project2/module6
module7

commits.title: Integration of the 3GPP TR 38.901 pathloss and channel condition model (GSoC 2019) (1/2)
commits.message:
Integration of the 3GPP TR 38.901 pathloss and channel condition model (GSoC 2019) (1/2)

In particular, this commit contains:

* a new abstract class ChannelConditionModel, which provides the base for the
 implementation of specific channel condition models. The main method is
 GetChannelCondition (mm a, mm b), which determines the channel condition
 based on the tx and rx mobility models and returns it as a pointer to an
 object of type ChannelCondition
* the implementation of the subclasses ThreeGppRMaChannelConditionModel,
 ThreeGppUMaChannelConditionModel, ThreeGppUMiStreetCanyonChannelConditionModel,
 ThreeGppIndoorMixedOfficeChannelConditionModel,
 ThreeGppIndoorOpenOfficeChannelConditionModel, which inherits from
 ChannelConditionModel and statistically determines the LOS/NLOS state based on
 the specification in 3GPP TR 38.901
* the implementation of the subclass BuildingsChannelConditionModel, which
 inherits from ChannelConditionModel and determines the LOS/NLOS state based
 on the buildings deployed in the scenario. It has been adapted from the
 mmwave module.
* new classes which extends the PropagationLossModel interface and implements
 the pathloss models defined in 3GPP TR 38.901
 (ThreeGppRmaPropagationLossModel, ThreeGppUmaPropagationLossModel,
 ThreeGppUmiStreeCanyonPropagationLossModel,
 ThreeGppIndoorOfficePropagationLossModel). The main method is DoCalcRxPower
 (txPow, mm a, mm b), which applies the pathloss model taking into account the
 LOS/NLOS channel state and then returns the received power. To retrieve the
 channel state, they interface with the class ChannelConditionModel through
 the method GetChannelCondition (mm a, mm b)
* documentation and test cases for all the new classes

commits.title: app: E2E stats header
commits.message:
app: E2E stats header

Right now, there is no way of extracting e2e statistics without using flow monitor. This patch enables, with an attribute, the possibility of adding a particular header to the outgoing packets, that will be read from PacketSink. The header contains Sequence, Size, and Timestamp, and therefore at the reception, it is possible to measure throughput and per-packet delay.

commits.title: core: (fixes 2815) Config::Connect should throw warnings
commits.message:
core: (fixes 2815) Config::Connect should throw warnings

This patch logs unconditionally when a trace path doesn't exist.

We also provide FailSafe versions of Config::Connect and
Config::ConnectWithoutContext.  These should be used when you
can't be sure that a trace path exists in the current model.

This resolves the warnings from AnimationInterface::ConnectCallbacks()

Credit to "InquisitivePenguin (GCI 2019) <>" for diagnosing this issue,
opening the way to a solution.

data.title: Priority queue
data.description:
This is three contributions.

1.  Complete the set of comparison operators (< == != >) for Event and EventKey
2.  Alexander Krotov's PriorityQueueScheduler, from [Bug 2503](https://www.nsnam.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=2503)
3.  GCI 2019 patch which implements Remove for the PriorityQueueScheduler (the underlying std::priority_scheduler doesn't support remove() natively.)

Please DO NOT SQUASH these on merge.

notes_data.body:
Hi Peter,

* Manual documentation seems missing about the complexity
* The previous point makes me wonder: do we have a manual section in which we explain our schedulers?

I'll add for this Scheduler.

No comprehensive complexity docs yet; see #139  

There is a placeholder in the Manual chapter on [Events and Simulator](https://www.nsnam.org/docs/manual/html/events.html#scheduler).

IMO we should also have that information on the Doxygen [Scheduler and Events](https://www.nsnam.org/docs/doxygen/group__scheduler.html) group.
